question: Which muscle group is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand and abducts the fingers?
short_explanation: The dorsal interossei abduct the fingers away from the midline.
long_explanation: The four dorsal interossei muscles are responsible for abducting the index, middle, and ring fingers. They originate from adjacent metacarpals and insert onto proximal phalanges and the extensor hood.
applied_example: Assessing finger abduction strength helps evaluate dorsal interossei function, especially in ulnar nerve assessments.
text: Which muscle group is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand and abducts the fingers?

question: The dorsal interossei are innervated by which nerve?
short_explanation: The ulnar nerve innervates the dorsal interossei.
long_explanation: The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies motor innervation to the dorsal interossei, which control finger abduction.
applied_example: Loss of ulnar nerve function leads to weakened finger abduction, affecting fine motor tasks like piano playing.
text: The dorsal interossei are innervated by which nerve?

question: Which digit has two dorsal interossei muscles acting on it?
short_explanation: The middle finger has two dorsal interossei for bidirectional abduction.
long_explanation: The middle finger can abduct in either direction and therefore has two dorsal interossei, one on each side, unlike other digits.
applied_example: Functional movement of the middle finger is a key test in dorsal interosseous muscle strength assessments.
text: Which digit has two dorsal interossei muscles acting on it?

question: Where do the dorsal interossei insert?
short_explanation: Dorsal interossei insert on the lateral sides of proximal phalanges.
long_explanation: These muscles insert onto the base of the proximal phalanges and the extensor expansion, aiding in both finger abduction and extension at the interphalangeal joints.
applied_example: Insertion points are important in surgeries or injuries requiring hand reconstruction or splinting.
text: Where do the dorsal interossei insert?
abcd: B. Lateral sides of proximal phalanges

question: The dorsal interossei assist in which joint movement?
short_explanation: They assist with flexion at the MCP joints.
long_explanation: By inserting into the extensor hood, the dorsal interossei contribute to flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints while extending the interphalangeal joints.
applied_example: Their dual action is important in rehabilitation of grip and hand coordination.
text: The dorsal interossei assist in which joint movement?

question: Which vascular structure supplies the dorsal interossei?
short_explanation: Dorsal metacarpal arteries supply the dorsal interossei.
long_explanation: The dorsal metacarpal arteries branch from the radial and ulnar arteries and provide blood to the dorsal interossei and surrounding tissues.
applied_example: Understanding blood supply is critical in evaluating tissue healing or planning surgical grafts.
text: Which vascular structure supplies the dorsal interossei?

question: Which dorsal muscle does not directly control digit movement?
short_explanation: Abductor pollicis longus abducts the thumb at the wrist joint.
long_explanation: Unlike other dorsal muscles that act on fingers, abductor pollicis longus abducts the thumb at the carpometacarpal joint and contributes to radial deviation.
applied_example: Understanding this action helps differentiate tendon injuries in the thumb region.
text: Which dorsal muscle does not directly control digit movement?

question: What hand deformity may result from loss of dorsal interossei function?
short_explanation: Loss of interossei function can contribute to claw hand deformity.
long_explanation: Without dorsal interossei to assist with MCP flexion and IP extension, the fingers hyperextend at the MCP and flex at the IP joints, resulting in claw hand.
applied_example: Massage therapists may assist in managing symptoms and compensatory muscle tension associated with claw hand.
text: What hand deformity may result from loss of dorsal interossei function?

question: Which of the following structures lies superficial to the dorsal interossei?
short_explanation: The dorsal aponeurosis lies superficial to the interossei.
long_explanation: The dorsal aponeurosis, or extensor expansion, receives contributions from the lumbricals and interossei and is visible on the back of the hand.
applied_example: Proper identification is critical in surgical planning and injury rehab to avoid damaging deeper muscle layers.
text: Which of the following structures lies superficial to the dorsal interossei?

question: What motion is most affected when dorsal interossei are paralyzed?
long_explanation: The dorsal interossei are the only muscles responsible for finger abduction. Their paralysis eliminates this movement, commonly seen in ulnar nerve injuries.
applied_example: Therapists may work to strengthen compensatory muscles or improve hand coordination during rehab for ulnar neuropathy.
text: What motion is most affected when dorsal interossei are paralyzed?
